comments.body: But did it receive restricted funding, was "significant" or "unrestricted" the problem before ? Do we need to invoke history before its definition here?

> But did it receive restricted funding, 

Yes, NumPy has received restricted funding. For details, refer to the section “History and current status” below.

In case you are not familiar with the internals of non-profit and academic funding, **restricted funds** are monies set aside for a particular purpose (e.g., project, educational program, etc.). They are **permanently restricted** to that purpose and cannot be used for any other expenses.  By contrast, unrestricted funds may be used for any legal purpose appropriate to the organization.

> was "significant" or "unrestricted" the problem before ? 

The lack of **unrestricted funds** was, and still remains, the biggest challenge.

> Do we need to invoke history before its definition here?

Initially, the History and Current Status section was a part of the Motivation and Scope. Its large wordcount made us concerned that it would be taking away readers’ attention from the objectives of this document. Hence, we moved it to the end. 
Would it help to insert a sentence at the beginning of this section linking to the section below? E.g., _For the overview of the NumPy funding history and current status please refer to [NumPy funding – history and current status](url)._

comments.body: What is a program?
@ilayn It’s another commonly used term in non-profit and academic funding. Would the word “purpose” be less confusing?

Since we expect this document to live for many years, I think rough dates would be more appropriate:
```
Since its inception and until 2020, the NumPy project has only seen about $10,000 of unrestricted* funding.

* unrestricted funding is money contributed to the project with no conditions for use: the project can decide to spend it on equipment, salary, conferences, or any other purpose as the project sees fit.
```

comments.body: I think the definition of un-unrestricted funds are in this sentence but I couldn't fully understand it. Though I feel what is mentioned here.

@ilayn Please refer to the comment above: https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/18454/commits/cf9a5db9bca7af3665c78c071cff49d36214481b#r580023603. 
Non-profit and academic funding is the world of its own.:)
If these terms have specific meanings that are not generally understood, they should be defined, maybe as footnotes.
@mattip @ilayn What do you think of a short glossary prefacing the document instead of the footnotes?
Any supplementary information like a glossary should be at the end, not the beginning.

If this is going to be read and not filed away I would expect a definition at the beginning. This is not an article after all so footnote I would really not bother with. It doesn't have to be a definition section anyways. I think the academic style is creeping in here.

This is exactly why I had the history section at the start. Basically, unrestricted funds are coming from donations, Tidelift monthly payments, GSoC mentoring fees, and other such things - income for the project that goes into our account and we don't already have a donation for.

This contrasts with grants and other types of contracts, which typically say "you get $xxx,000 for deliverables Y or activities Z".
So then if we connect that history to what you just wrote here, I'm sold. I just need to get an understanding of what restricted means such that the rest is easy to parse.

> If this is going to be read and not filed away 

If we are successful in our fundraising efforts, I expect this NEP to be used on a regular basis.

comments.body:
Sorry if it is clarified somewhere below--given two approximately equivalently-skilled candidates working in locations that might justify paying one candidate substantially less than the other, will the lower-burden candidate have preference on the basis of being able to perform x % more work for the available funds?

That is kind of like dumping the outsourcing debate on this NEP, but the the cost of living matter is indeed discussed here in some detail so it is hard to avoid thinking that this might be an ethical dilemma of sorts (it is addressed by the fully-remote i.e., GitLab policies?).

@tylerjereddy I understand your concerns. Personally, I encourage the NumPy Steering Council, the body that is currently in charge of hiring decisions, to be “location-blind” in a selection of contractors and choose the best candidate for the job/task. After all, NumPy is a not-for-profit project.

Location is one factor that determines how contractors spend their money. Factors like supporting family could be considered even more important than location as the contractors' families may vary a lot in size and nature. That said, I think the location and other similar factors should be discarded when negotiating the contract terms. To get the job done well and quickly defines the efficiency of spending project funds, not how contractors are likely to spend their pays - it is nobody's business, imho.

@tylerjereddy @pearu Thank you for taking part in this very important discussion. Would you mind copying your comments to the NumPy mailing list? According to the NumPy governance document (https://numpy.org/doc/stable/dev/governance/governance.html), this type of discussion should take place there. 
You are welcome to leave comments here, on GitHub, if you catch a typo or have minor suggestions for improving the text of this document.
https://mail.python.org/pipermail/numpy-discussion/2021-February/081531.html
Given the amount of discussion and that we don't have experience with doing this yet, I added:

comments.body:
```suggestion

NumPy is a fiscally sponsored project of NumFOCUS, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization headquartered in Austin, TX. Therefore, for all legal and accounting matters the NumPy project has to follow the rules and regulations for US nonprofits. All nonprofit donations are classified into two categories: **unrestricted funds** which may be used for any legal purpose appropriate to the organization and **restricted funds**, monies set aside for a particular purpose (e.g., project, educational program, etc.). It’s important to note that restricted funds are **permanently restricted** to that purpose and cannot be used for any other expenses.  

For the detailed timeline of NumPy funding refer to [NumPy funding – history and current status](#history-and-current-status).

```
This reads much much better now for the rest of the history to follow.

Thanks @InessaPawson. I'm not sure the "permanently restricted" bit is technically true or necessary, probably best left out. But for now this added paragraph helps people understand the rest better, so I'll commit it as-is.
@rgommers You are right, it's better to leave the fourth sentence out.

```suggestion
See references. We assume that other open source projects have also developed guidelines on spending project funds. However, we were unable to find any examples at the time of writing.
```

comments.body:
```suggestion
.. note::
The authors of this NEP are not fully settled on the approach described below and would like to put it in practice at least with 2-3 hires before submitting a final recommendation.
```
what about work needing specific skills that are not present within the maintainers and volunteers groups?

This indeed can happen. The first principle in "what to pay for" says to pay for things that otherwise won't get done. One reason something doesn't get done is because the required skills are missing in the project/community.

I think we are missing skills, but more outside of development work. It's very well possible that it's a combination of a rare skill and no one in the team with bandwidth + motivation to address the need.

So we look outside of the community to find the right person. I think that's addressed in the next section ("who to pay").
